ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was a live virtual lecture but with quite a bit of discussion on certain days, office hours also ran more like a seminar.
Live virtual lecture with recordings of lecture posted and twice weekly study halls.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of important basics of astrophysics, from orbital dynamics to fluid dynamics. We learned how to use programming to evaluate differential equations over time, and did many homework questions that provided us with code that will be useful in my future astronomy projects!
Developed a thorough understanding of applying physical measurements to astronomical systems.

This course provided an overview of some of the important physics applications to astronomy. We also worked on some general codes that could be useful in future research in common simulations and calculations. The course also engaged with different media sources and recent papers to help us prepare for how to approach astro news and developments as astronomers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course's main strength is the enthusiasm of Professor Laughlin, who makes the class incredibly productive and engaging at the same time.
Strength was in subject area and teaching.

I really enjoyed the media and current events inclusion. The community and small class also made it a more comfortable environment, and I think the office hours were useful when I could attend. I think communication to students could have been a bit better about deadline extensions, whether there would be a midterm or not, etc.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the lectures were really fluid and interesting, and I thought that Professor Laughlin's use of an iPad whiteboard was a nice way to make the class feel as though it was in person. This also allowed for more engagement from the class.
Virtual lecture worked well enough, but engagement during seminar was low.

I liked the live lectures, as I've been struggling with asynchronous lectures, but appreciate that they were also recorded to accommodate time zones, people who like asynchronous lectures, or not being worried about missing a live lecture when things came up.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would! I think it is both informative and quite useful as an intro to many big concepts in astronomy, and also gives you some good coding skills for future work.
Yes, an important staple to the astro major.

I would recommend it to other astro students, mostly because we have to take it, but also especially with Greg since I've heard some complaints about other profs. teaching it in the past. As for physics majors looking for an astro elective, I think there are probably some more niche and interesting electives as this covers a pretty broad array of topics.
